results.title: Liszt and his music
results.brief_description: The life of Franz Liszt, as musical composer, performer and teacher presented against a background of the European capitals where he composed and performed. Includes excerpts from the following works: Concerto No. 1 in E Flat Mojor; Hungarian Rhapsody No. 2; Sonata in B Minor and Les Preludes. Particular attention is given to the latter piece as an example of the symphonic poem.

results.title: Listening: a key to problem solving
results.creator_credit: Donald R. Ham, Robert Boucher, A. Scott Miller and Paramount Communications
results.brief_description: A dramatised view of how well listening occurs in an office situation. An employee is promoted despite his verbal and non verbal objections, and problems arise. Solutions to the problem are explored as the film points out listening techniques which will reduce problems and improve working relationships.

results.title: Listening to good music: the string quartet
results.brief_description: A string quartet illustrates the fundamentals of group musical performance. The range and distinctive qualities of each instrument are identified, then combined to show how the four voices develop form and mood. Excerpts from quartets by Mozart, Haydn and Schubert are used to show the relationship of performer to composer, and of the performers to each other.

results.title: Listening beyond words
results.creator_credit: Keith J. Atkinson, Welzel O. Whitaker and Brigham Young University
results.brief_description: At times the whole world listens for much is at stake. Many sounds compete for our attention the louder ones are often missed. Listening is essential to true communication and although 70% of our time is estimated to be spent in communication and listening takes up the bulk of that time it is often done badly. In personal relations or at work or at school, we should listen not merely for information, but also for understanding. Real listening is not passive, in the end it saves time and sometimes money.

results.title: Listen! Hear!
results.brief_description: Introduces the concept of vibration and shows how sound waves are produced and can be measured. An animated sequence illustrates the structures of the three parts of the ear and how sound waves are received and translated.

results.brief_description: Explores causes of hearing loss due to excess noise experienced in modern living. Various ways of reducing the possibility of long-term damage are suggested.

results.title: Listen up my cherubs!
results.creator_credit: Karen Milward, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Energetic and intelligent, Karen Milward is constantly engaged with life. Often on the road for her work in the Aboriginal community, her children wonder what it is she actually does. This story is by way of explanation and gives insight into the life of an amazing community worker and consultant.

results.title: Listen to us - the way we speak. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Barbara Wethey and Inner London Education Authority
results.brief_description: Part 1. “Listen to us”: “Linguistic and Cultural Diversity”. Britain now has a multi-ethnic and multicultural society which is also multilingual. This program acknowledges that diversity in order to benefit pupils. Part 4. “The Way We Speak”: “Considering Dialect and Learning”. Considers whether schools should permit and teach dialects of the English language. In both of these programs we see activities which may help to develop and reinforce language, showing teachers using the activities in actual classrooms. Companion videotape “Working Together in the Classroom; Supporting Understanding”

results.creator_credit_for_label: Barbara Wethey and Inner London Education Authority
